_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chlorine is the most commonly used substance for disinfecting drinking water. The addition of chlorine or chlorine compounds to water is called chlorination. Chlorination is considered to be the most important process for preventing the spread of waterborne disease in drinking water. The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power (LADWP) also uses chlorine for drinking water disinfection purposes at the Upper Stone Canyon Station to protect public health per state and federal water quality standards.
      The LADWP Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station (USCCS) chlorine handling process is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program and Plan and to the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program and Plan requirements. The chlorination facility is also subject to the California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (Cal/OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard. The facilities subject to the EPA and the CalARP regulations are required to prepare and update Risk Management Plans (RMPs). An update of the RMP is required at least once every five years from the date of its initial submission. The RMP is to include policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility and the actions, which will be taken by the facility in the event of an emergency.
      The LADWP prepared Program 3 Risk Management Plan for the USCCS in June 2019. This 2024 update of the 2019 RMP for USCCS also demonstrates compliance with Program 3 requirements.
      The following information is specifically required in the RMP Executive Summary: 
* Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
* General facility and regulated substances information.
* Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.
* Five-year accident history summary.
* Emergency response program summary.
* Planned changes to improve safety.
      The above information for the Upper Stone Can

yon Chlorination Station is provided below.
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
      The LADWP accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates the use of proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices. All applicable requirements of the State of California and the EPA's Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.  
      The LADWP emergency response policy involves the preparation of emergency response plans for hazardous materials, which are tailored to each facility and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with the EPA Emergency Response Program Requirements. The LADWP has prepared an Emergency Response Plan for the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station to facilitate coordination and emergency planning with offsite response officials and facilities in the event of an emergency. The Emergency Response Plan has been coordinated with the local response agency (City of Los Angeles Fire Department). 
General Facility and Regulated Substance Information
      The Upper Stone Canyon Station is located at 1900 North Stone Canyon Road in Los Angeles, California. There are multiple chlorine feed points on the reservoir complex property to disinfect water in Upper and Lower Stone Canyon Reservoirs, the Upper Stone Canyon bypass pipelines #1 and #2, and the membrane filtration plant. The treated water is piped into the distribution network, which serves parts of west Los Angeles with potable water.
      The chlorination station building consists of a chlorine storage room, chlorine equipment room, an electrical equipment room, several chemical storage rooms, and a 4,700-lb capacity dry media scrubber room. The chlorination station uses ton containers for storing chlorine. A maximum of 22 ton containers c

an be stored at the USCCS.
      The design incorporates two banks of four ton containers each, which normally feed liquid chlorine to evaporators. There is an automatic switchover system that determines which liquid chlorine header feeds the evaporators. This system consists of a control panel, two motorized ball valves, and a pressure switch on the liquid header before the evaporators. When the pressure in the liquid chlorine supply line drops to 20 psi, the switchover system opens the valve isolating the standby bank of ton containers to allow liquid chlorine to flow. At the same time, it closes the ball valve on the now empty bank of ton containers. A third bank of two ton containers is also provided. These two ton containers connect to a gas header which leads to three automatic switchover type vacuum regulating valves in parallel acting as an automatic backup gas supply. 
      The system is also configured with gas headers for each of the two banks of four ton containers. This is essentially a complete gas feed system with automatic switchover capability. It can be used during periods of low chlorine demand, or if the liquid system is out of service for repairs. 
      The gaseous chlorine from the evaporators or from the chlorine gas header proceeds to the chlorinators that regulate chlorine flow and feed. Chlorine gas from the vacuum regulating valve (VRV) with check-relief units is pulled by vacuum to the chlorinators and then to the injectors. It is important to note that in case of loss of vacuum downstream of the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief units, the VRV will close, and only air would be drawn in rather than chlorine gas being released. In addition, the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit will shut down the chlorine supply to the chlorinator, operating as a shut-off valve. 
      The chlorinators supply gaseous chlorine to the plant injection systems. Chlorine gas is withdrawn from the chlorinators under vacuum to the injectors

. In the injectors, chlorine mixes with a high-pressure water supply to form a concentrated solution. The chlorine solution discharged from the injector is diffused into the pipelines or the reservoirs through multiple diffuser nozzles.
      Main Process control is performed by Programmable Logic Controllers (PLC) that determines the feed rate relative to the residual and water flow rates. Flow signals are transmitted to the controller.  
      The chlorine storage and chlorinator rooms are equipped with chlorine leak detectors and are tied into the Leak Detector Control Panels in the chlorine control room. Additional chlorine detectors are located in the suction and discharge ducts for the chlorine main scrubber and the mini-scrubber. The detectors in the chlorine storage and chlorinator rooms are able to detect and provide warning of the presence of chlorine gas in the air, giving a locally audible and flashing/strobe red light alarm when chlorine concentration exceeds 1 ppm by volume. The main scrubber room is equipped with a chlorine leak detector, which turns off the room ventilation system at 1 ppm. The outputs from the detectors are monitored by the SCADA system. The values can be read and alarms are generated by the system computer at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) control room. Additionally, an audio alarm is initiated to further alert control room personnel. The chlorine detector system has a battery backup. Thus, the detector system will continue operating even during a power failure.
      All the ton containers connected to the process are equipped with automatic shutoff valve actuators which shut off the ton container angle valves when desired. These actuators close all ten ton containers (two banks of four ton containers each and one bank of two ton containers) that are connected to either the liquid or gas headers when any two of the chlorine gas detectors in the chlorine container or chlorinator rooms detect gas exceeding 10 ppm.

A dry media type chlorine gas scrubber system (main scrubber) is installed at the station. The unit is actuated by chlorine detectors at a chlorine concentration of 3 ppm. The scrubber can neutralize up to 4,700 lbs. of chlorine in case of a chlorine leak. The scrubber draws suction from the chlorine storage, evaporator and chlorinator rooms through a duct. The scrubber is programmed to automatically shut off once the chlorine detectors no longer detect a chlorine concentration of 3 ppm. The station is equipped with an uninterruptible power supply (UPS) in addition to a backup power generator. Therefore, in case of the failure of regular power, the scrubber will remain functional.
      A dry media chlorine "mini-scrubber" unit (MS) has also been installed at the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station. The MS is an emergency chlorine scrubber intended to protect personnel working in the building or immediate area from a chlorine gas release from the pressure safety relief vent provided in the vacuum regulator check units. Mini-scrubber can neutralize up to 25 lbs. of chlorine, and the media manufacturer specifies chlorine removal to less than 5 parts per billion. The scrubber starts automatically when chlorine concentration at the inlet detector exceeds 1 ppm. The mini-scrubber exhausts near the main scrubber intake in the evaporator room. 
      In the event power is lost at the chlorine facilities, an alarm will alert the LAAFP control room. Chlorine flow will continue unaffected, with no safety consequences. An emergency generator will automatically start and supply power to the entire system. An emergency generator will automatically start and supply power to the entire system. Access to the facility is through gates, which are kept locked all the time.
Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
      The LADWP accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:
* Detailed managem

ent system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
* Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
* Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
* Performance of process hazard analysis review of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.
* State-of-the-art process and safety equipment.
* Accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the station operators.
* High level training for the operators and maintenance staff.
* A State of California Water Treatment Facility Staff Certification is required to operate the station.
* An incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.
      Chemical-specific prevention steps include the following: availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine supply; awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine; presence of chlorine detectors and alarms with remote monitoring, use of automatic shutoff valve actuators, chlorine main scrubber; and a chlorine mini-scrubber.
Process and Chemical Safety Information
      Comprehensive chemical data has been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine. This information includes chlorine background information and Safety Data Sheets.
      Equipment safety information was compiled on the chlorine process. Specifications for the chlorine process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference. Details (such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; and safe upper and lower pressures for the chlorination facility) are on file at the facility. The LADWP also has procedures in place that are triggered to update process safety information if there is a major ch

ange that makes existing information inaccurate.
Process Hazard Analysis
      A PHA for the chlorination process was performed in March 2024 for updating/revalidating the previously performed PHA in 2019. This PHA will be updated/revalidated again within a five-year period or whenever there will be a major change in the process. A set of recommendations was made to further improve the chlorine safety. These recommendations are being evaluated for implementation. The LADWP staff will document the completion of the recommended actions. 
      A seismic assessment, including the walkthrough of the chlorination facility on April 10, 2024 was completed in June 2024. A set of recommendations was developed  to further improve the chlorine safety during future earthquakes. All of these recommendations are being evaluated for implementation. The LADWP staff will document the completion of the recommended actions. 
Operating Procedures
      The LADWP has prepared written operating procedures for Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station that provide clear instructions or steps for safely conducting activities relating to chlorination process. They are consistent with the chlorine safety information. Written operating procedures included in the facility's Operation and Maintenance (O&M) Manual are as follows:
* Delivery of Chlorine.
* Ton Container Connections.
* Initial Startup Procedure.
* Normal Operation.
* Normal Shutdown.
* Temporary Operations.
* Emergency Operations.
* Emergency Shutdown.
* Startup Following Emergency Shutdown.
Training
      The LADWP ensures that each employee operating or maintaining the chlorination process, and each employee newly assigned to this process, is trained and tested for competency in the operating procedures listed above. LADWP employee training documentation files include training records for each employee assigned to operate or maintain the chlorination process. The training ensures that the employee has the required knowledge, skill

s, and abilities to safely perform the duties and responsibilities, including chlorine emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures. Employee training includes as a minimum the following elements:
* Safety Information.
* Process Technology and Process Equipment, including safety systems.
* Maintenance Procedures.
* Operating Procedures for the chlorine system.
* RMP Program contents.
* Emergency Response Plan and Procedures.
      Refresher training is provided at least every three years to each employee operating the chlorination process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures. In addition, the LADWP ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after major modifications.  
Contractors
      The LADWP Contractor's procedures specify the information required to be provided to the contractors performing work on or near the chlorination process, the training requirements for contractor employees, and mechanism to obtain assurance from contractors that they have informed their employees of the appropriate safety rules. The LADWP provides information and explanations concerning the hazards and processes. 
Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program
      The LADWP has procedures in place to ensure that a pre-startup safety review is conducted prior to starting a new covered process or prior to making modifications to the chlorination systems that require a Management of Change (MOC) procedure implementation. The required conditions prior to startup include the following:
* Construction and/or equipment are in accordance with design specifications.
* Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate.
* A PHA has been performed for any new facilities and recommendations have been resolved or implemented prior to startup.
* At modified facilities, MOC requirements have been met.
* Training of each operating a

nd maintenance employee involved in the process is complete.
      These procedures ensure that no new and/or new/significantly modified process will startup and no regulated substances will be introduced into such a process before the pre-startup safety review. This constitutes a final check that the process and equipment are ready to go and that the recommendations of the PHA have been implemented or adequately addressed. This will ensure that the design and construction of a new or modified process is safely executed and that the facility is prepared to operate it. 
      Mechanical integrity procedures for the plant ensure that written maintenance procedures are implemented and documented, including training of maintenance personnel.
Maintenance 
      The LADWP operates a Computerized Maintenance Management System (CMMS) software Program, an asset management program that generates a preventive maintenance work order at a designated frequency. Description of the work to be performed is included with the printed work order. The water treatment supervisor is responsible for this task.
      In addition, the written maintenance procedure is provided in the O&M Manual as follows: Preventive maintenance schedules are provided which summarize inspection, test, and maintenance schedules on a daily, weekly, bi-monthly, monthly, biannual, and annual, every 2 to 10 years, and as-needed basis. These procedures allow the operator to rapidly review what maintenance is necessary.
      The LADWP documents inspection, testing, and maintenance of chlorination equipment and assures the performance is performed in accordance with the recommendations of the manufacturer and industry groups.
Hot Work Permits and Management of Change
      Hot work refers to work involving electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing, or similar flame or spark producing operations. The hot work procedures require the issuance of a hot work permit whenever it is conducted on or near the chlorination pro

cess and other areas deemed appropriate as described in these procedures. Fire prevention and protection systems are in place before a hot work permit is issued. The permit indicates the dates the work is authorized for, the location, and specific operational requirements, and it is kept on file in the administrative office. 
      The LADWP Management of Change procedures include steps required to be taken by plant personnel before implementing changes to chlorination equipment, procedures, raw materials, and processing conditions. Training, process safety information, operating procedures, and maintenance procedures are updated according to the changes made.
Internal Compliance Audits
      The LADWP has been certifying every three years (or earlier) that compliance with Prevention Program requirements is met and that procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed. The two most recent audit reports and a list of the recommendations are retained in the LADWP's files.
      The compliance audit for the chlorination station consists of separating the RMP program elements or sections and auditing each element to determine compliance and effectiveness. For each internal audit, the audit team completes a Compliance Audit Certification Page and a Compliance Audit Checklist. The Compliance Audit Certification Page provides process identification, the dates of the audit, team members, and certification by the audit leader. The Compliance Audit Checklist details the requirements of each RMP element and contains questions that may assist with the auditing process. The audit checklist for each element consists of the following three sections:
* Records Review: A review of the RMP written Prevention Program.
* On-Site Conditions: The audit team will review the program elements based on observation of the plant conditions and safety practices.
* Interviews: The program elements will be evaluated by interviewing personnel from appropriate functions including

operations, maintenance, management, and contractors.
      Compliance Auditor records RMP program deficiencies identified during the audit on the checklist.
Incident Investigation
      The LADWP incident investigation procedures describe incident reporting, investigation, and investigation reporting steps to be followed by plant personnel. The incident investigation is started promptly but no later than 48 hours after the event. The LADWP promptly addresses and resolves all recommendations and implements the recommendations in a timely manner to prevent an incident recurrence. All incident investigation reports are retained in the LADWP's file for at least a period of five years from the date the reports are completed.
Five-year Accident History Summary
      No chlorine release that could have caused safety or health hazard (on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place) occurred at the USCCS during the last five years. 
Emergency Response Program Summary
      The LADWP is a first responder, its employees respond to chlorine accidental releases. In the event an accidental release that could result in offsite consequences occurs, external resources, such as the City of Los Angeles Fire Department will also be solicited to respond.  
      As part of the emergency response program, the LADWP has developed and implemented an emergency response plan for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment. The following elements are included:
(a) Emergency response plan, maintained at the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination and Ammoniation Stations and at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) containing:
* Organizational structure (chain-of-command) and responsibilities of various LADWP personnel.
* Procedures for planning and coordination with off-site emergency response organizations.
* Details of the training programs for all emplo

yees involved with the chlorination process, contractor training, and medical surveillance of LADWP personnel who respond to chlorine releases.
* Details of emergency recognition and prevention at the LADWP.
* Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases.
* Documentation of proper first aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures and the detailed information on emergency health care.
* Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release.
(b)	Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection, testing, and maintenance. 
(c)	Training in relevant procedures for all employees involved with the chlorination process.
(d)	Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes and ensure that employees are informed of changes.
Planned Changes to Improve Safety
      Based on the 2019 PHA, nine recommendations were made for the USCCS to improve chlorine safety. These recommendations have been evaluated, and implemented or adequately addressed by the LADWP. Additionally, a set of recommendations to further improve chlorine safety were made in 2024, when PHA was updated/revalidated for the USCCS.
      Based on the 2019 seismic assessment for the USCCS, three recommendations were made to improve chlorine safety. These recommendations have been evaluated, and implemented or adequately addressed by the LADWP.
      Based on the 2024 seismic assessment update for the USCCS, a set of recommendations has been made to further improve the chlorine safety during future earthquakes.
      It is expected that all the above 2024 recommendations will be evaluated, and implemented or adequately addressed by the LADWP by September 2026. The implementation of these recommendations will further enhance the safety of the chlorination station.
